Figure 3.4:1 -Two orthographic views of the spherical SOM trained on 1.1M books, coloured through PCA colourisation. Figure 3.4:2 - Flattened Hammer projection of the PCA coloured spherical SOM All books are then projected onto the SOM and assigned to a cell. This populated SOM is whosn in Figure 3.4:3. Figure 3.4:3 - Flattened Hammer projection with a heat-map of the projected number of books onto the SOM 1525 is the maximum number per cell, 0 the lowest Figure 3.4:4 - Activations of books in the dataset at indices 0, to 1,100,000 at 100,000 intervals The next step is the reason for using a spherical SOM in this particular instance instead of a toroid. The ambition was to make an ultra light measurement to establish which books should be retrieved, based on first global topic the location on the full som and second the internal cell 'altitude' of a book. This altitude was determined by fitting a PCA perpendicular to the 300 dimensional surface of the spherical SOM. The idea is that because the SOM is spherical the altitude also gives an impression of genericness internal to the SOM, negative altitude or unusual external to the SOM, high altitude. This approach is the result of an earlier experiment which is included in the appendix. Figure 3.4:5 - Example of an activation by book index 0 and the altitude of that book in each cell of the som. Figure 3.4:6 - Zoomed in altitude mapping on the activated region of the SOM The altitudes within a cell represent the "spread" of the conversations that particular cell can accomodate. An example of the internal altitudes for cell number 4250 is given in Figure 3.4:7. This cell was chosen as a demonstration because it holds a relatively small number of books, allowing for a more legible spectrum. Figure 3.4:7 - Altitudes of the book population of cell 4250 the one including Norwegian Wood by Haruki Murakami. paragraph For the paragraph level we do not build a unifying structure, but instead rely on a two-tier vectorial search only. This is because of two reasons, first of all the paragraph section itself is of a dynamic nature because it is intended to be changed per chapter in WIPT. Secondly, the search onto the paragraph set is highly volatile because it is the constantly changing writing, so a unifying layer that is able to make a curation of things that represent a broader spectrum like with the books is net desired, instead it forcuses on specific and relevant retrievel to the constantly changing writing. The exact implementation is discussed in 3.6, as it falls under the interaction level of the editor scheme. paragraph - The embedding process of each space. - How each element is contextualised - Variety of vectorisations used - Use of different SOMs - Experiment of image by image SOM - Distinction between figurative and textual words FIGURATIVE

*The activation of a cell can be seen as a snapshot of the conversation or topic that dominates that region of the SOM. The internal altitudes within a cell represent the spread or diversity of the conversations that particular cell can accommodate. As shown in Figure 3.4:7, the cell 4250 holds a relatively small number of books, allowing for a more legible spectrum of internal altitudes. The altitudes within a cell can be used to filter the retrieved books to those that are most relevant to the topic of the cell. For example, in the case of cell 4250, books with altitudes close to the mean altitude of the cell are likely to be more representative of the topic than those with altitudes far from the mean. This approach allows for a more fine-grained retrieval of relevant books based on their proximity to the topic of interest. The internal altitudes can also be used to identify clusters or groups of books within a cell that share similar characteristics. This can be seen as a way to uncover hidden patterns or relationships between the books and the topic of interest.*
